titleStmt.title: Belief updates, learning and adaptive decision making

analytic.title: Belief updates, learning and adaptive decision making

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: People make decisions every day and the outcomes of those decisions often lead them to change their beliefs and in some cases shape their future behavior. How does the brain decide which meal to order at a restaurant, and how does it learn from the experience of eating that meal? Here we review work from neuroscience, psychology and economics that shapes our understanding of how the brain makes decisions and learns through experience. We focus on computational mechanisms that can explain core phenomena in learning and decision making as well as how such mechanisms are implemented in the brain. Our review highlights both the considerable progress made in the last decades elucidating mechanisms of learning and decision making as well as the vast territory of open questions that remain to be answered.

div.head: Introduction:
div.p: How do I decide which restaurant to eat at? How do I form and update the beliefs about the world that shape my behavior, from my food preferences to career path? The brain makes decisions large and small that shape our lives and experience. Most of these decisions are based on learned expectations about the world, or beliefs, that are updated dynamically according to ongoing experience. In this article we examine the cognitive, computational, and neural mechanisms that underlie learning and decision making. We first summarize the key advances in our understanding of learning and decision-making research separately and then re-evaluate these findings within a general computation-centered framework (Fig 1). Framework for learning and decision making. Learning and decision-making involve use of prior knowledge from previous experience as well as momentary sensory information in order to compute key decision variables, such as the values of available cognitive and physical actions. These decision variables guide selection of cognitive actions, including the decision to collect more information from the external environment or internal knowledge stores (white dotted lines), as well as physical actions, for example to order a specific item on the menu. Feedback about such actions is provided in the form of a new experience, which in turn shapes both internal knowledge structures through learning as well as the observable sensory environment (black dotted lines). Decision making research typically focuses on how decision variables are formed and used to select actions, whereas learning research typically focuses on how new experience shapes internal representations that drive behavior. Nonetheless, these processes are intertwined and share a common computational framework that contains elements including information sampling, context dependent belief updating, and higher order cost-benefit decisions that guide how these computations unfold.

div.head: Learning in the brain.
div.p: People exist in a complex and changing world and are forced to interact with it in order to achieve biological and psychological objectives. Developing an understanding of the world around us, and how our interactions with it alter the state of the world and ourselves, is critical for survival over evolutionary timescales and for selecting actions congruent with our goals in everyday life. People use beliefs about the world and the consequences of their own actions to shape their own behavior and update these beliefs according to a continuous stream of experience. These updated beliefs alter the way a person behaves in the future, in some cases facilitating appropriate goal-congruent behaviors, but in other cases promoting pathological patterns of behavior. In this article we explore what is known about how the brain learns to make decisions, relying on the notion of beliefs as an intermediary between our learning about the world and its consequences on our behavior.

For purposes of this article, we will consider learning to be an experience dependent change in a system, that often leads the system to produce different outputs (behavior) in response to the same inputs (situations). By this definition, learning is a pervasive phenomenon in biology, having been observed in some form in even single celled organisms. However, in this article we will focus on learning in the human brain, our understanding of which has been shaped both by experiments in humans as well as those in animal models for human learning.

div.head: Why do we learn?
div.p: Before diving into the full set of experiments and ideas that shape our understanding of learning in the human brain, it is worth stepping back to consider a more basic question, which is why do we learn at all? The behavior of people, and to some degree all animals with a central nervous system, is highly contingent on past experience. Even a single experience can often change the way we respond to a specific circumstance. Why? Perhaps, from an evolutionary perspective, we might operate under the assumption that there is something useful about being able to adapt our behavior according to the past. However, this is not a particularly satisfying answer to the question, since it doesn't give us any indication of particular types of learning we might expect to see, or particular types of learning we might not expect to see.

One set of ideas that provides a more specific view on why we learn comes from Bayesian theories of learning (Courville et al., 2006). The basic notion in these theories is that learning serves to perform an inference process, essentially using past experience to infer unobservable features of the world through iterative application of Bayes' Rule (Parr et al., 2018). This inference process is useful if the past has some bearing on the future, as in such cases learning about the world might provide some insights about what is to come, for example, which actions might be met with the most desirable outcomes (FeldmanHall & Nassar, 2021). Bayesian Brain theories provide an intuitive high-level framework for thinking about why a system might learn: to concisely summarize the past in a manner that predicts the present and future, thereby facilitating the selection of actions with desirable consequences.

One particularly useful construct from Bayesian Brain theory is that of a belief. In Bayesian inference, we can use prior experience to update "beliefs" about the world (Fig 2). For example, after seeing the co-occurence of two stimuli (a sound and a light) I might form a belief that the conditional probability of seeing a light after hearing the sound is high. Given some assumptions about the world, beliefs provide a mathematical formalism for combining various sources of information into a single numerical representation of the world that includes information about a quantity of interest (eg. will a light come on?) as well as uncertainty on our estimate of that quantity. While Bayes rule provides a statistical framework for updating beliefs, it is silent on which beliefs should be represented in the brain. A prior belief is iteratively updated using Bayes' rule. While initially, the value is expected to be 5 with low certainty (wide distribution), as values centered on 8 are repeatedly observed, the belief is iteratively updated and the observer comes to expect, with increasing certainty (narrower distributions), that the true underlying distribution is centered on 8.

One quantity of particular behavioral importance is the valence of a particular experience. Thorndyke's law of effect, proposed in 1905, stipulates that actions that are followed by positively valenced outcomes tend to be repeated in the future. This general idea has been refined over the last century, with a major breakthrough provided by Rescorla and Wagner, who developed a model of classical conditioning based on a set of update equations in which the association between a neutral conditioned stimulus (CS) and a valenced unconditioned stimulus (US) is adjusted upon observing a CS-US pairing according to the difference between the maximal US response and the acquired associative strength (Rescorla & Wagner, 1972). This model explains a wide range of phenomena in rodents and humans, and inspired computer scientists Richard Sutton and Andrew Barto to develop a class of semi-supervised learning algorithms based on the same learning principle, known collectively as reinforcement learning (Sutton & Barto, 2018). Reinforcement learning extended on the Rescorla Wagner rule in several ways. The first extension is largely philosophical: instead of updating conditioned responding toward a maximal value defined by the unconditioned stimulus, reinforcement learning models define an abstract quantity called reward, which serves as a proxy for the valence of experience. Second, reinforcement learning models define states as different situations in which an agent might want to learn an appropriate behavior. Reinforcement learning provides learning rules, inspired by the Rescorla and Wagner algorithm that use reward prediction errors to learn the value of actions in different states, thereby facilitating behavioral policies (which might require extended sequences of actions) that can maximize rewards over the long run. In short, reinforcement learning translates a successful description of conditioning behavior into an integrated framework for updating beliefs about action values that can be used to select behaviors that maximize the reward that they will yield in the long run.

div.head: Reinforcement learning for adaptive behavior.
div.p: Reinforcement learning has provided a fruitful framework for understanding learning in the brain. The first major insight from reinforcement learning came as the speculation that the key "teaching" signal for RL models might be instantiated in the firing of ascending dopamine neurons that project from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to the striatum (Montague et al., 1996). A reward prediction error signal that transfers learning across time using states, also called a temporal difference reward prediction error, should have a number of key properties: 1) it should be enhanced after reward, 2) it should be mitigated if that reward is predicted, 3) it should be enhanced in response to a cue that predicts a reward, 4) it should be diminished if a reward is omitted after such a cue. Each of these properties was observed in a single experiment in which rhesus macaques underwent a standard pavlovian conditioning paradigm in which liquid rewards were preceded by specific visual cues (Schultz et al., 1997). Further investigations revealed that the VTA responses highly sensitive to learning, not simply reward history (Waelti et al., 2001), that dopamine levels in downstream targets also fulfilled basic criteria of reward prediction errors in operant learning tasks (Hart et al., 2014), and that optogenetic manipulation of VTA neurons can increase or decrease learning consistent with their activity reflecting a reward prediction error (Maes et al., 2020;Steinberg et al., 2013). In short, over the last three decades, there has been considerable support for the idea that dopaminergic projects from the VTA to the striatum provide the sort of reward prediction error signals that are used in reinforcement learning to "train" action values.

But where are the action values? One influential theory suggests that the values of selecting a specific action in a specific state is stored in the connections between neurons that encode states and neurons that represent candidate actions that could be selected within that state. This theory suggests that dopamine RPE signals are used to adjust the weights of striatal synapses between cortical projection fibers and their downstream targets, the GABAergic medium spiny neurons (MSNs) (Frank et al., 2004). In principle, such a framework could allow cortical inputs ("states") to be linked with MSNs encoding alternative actions that have historically been the most rewarding in those states. Under this view, if cortical inputs encode a specific situation, and a downstream MSN encodes a selected action, then a positive RPE provided by dopaminergic projections would strengthen the connection between the state and the action, whereas a negative RPE signaled by the absence of dopamine would weaken it. In this way, a dopaminergic signal might "teach" corico-striatal circuits to build associations between situations and the actions that yield the highest rewards within them.

This theory builds on well established anatomical work detailing two pathways through the striatum that have opposite consequences in terms of their thalamicocortical outputs. MSNs in the direct pathway inhibit neurons in the globus pallidus internal (GPi), which in turn inhibit excitatory neuron in the thalamus, such that stimulation of direct pathway neurons amplifies thalamocortical outputs via disinhibition (Albin et al., 1989). In contrast, MSNs in the indirect pathway inhibit downstream targets in globus pallidus external (GPe), which inhibit downstream targets in GPi, which in turn inhibit thalamic excitatory neurons, leading activation of indirect pathway neurons to reduce thalamocortical transmission (Albin et al., 1989). Dopamine has differential effects on these pathways, since direct pathway MSNs tend to have a higher density of G_s coupled D1 type dopamine receptors, which increase activity and calcium signaling indirectly through a cyclic AMP-dependent signaling pathway. In contrast, indirect pathway MSNs tend to have a higher density of G_i coupled D2 type dopamine receptors, which inhibit adenylyl cyclase in the presence of dopamine, thereby reducing calcium levels and neural activity. The functional consequence of this receptor distribution is that a transient increase in dopamine levels in the striatum produces an increased activity in the direct pathway and reduced activity in the indirect pathway (Gerfen, 2023). One result of this for behavior would be increased bias toward action, or its cognitive equivalent, since the system is primed to translate cortical inputs into thalamic outputs. But a second result is that when coupled with Hebbian plasticity this receptor segregation would strengthen active synapses in the direct pathway after positive reward prediction errors (thereby biasing the system to select the rewarded action again in the future) but strengthen synapses in the indirect pathway after receiving a negative reward prediction error (thereby biasing the system to avoid selecting the punished action again in the future). The results of this learning asymmetry can be observed under pathological signaling in Parkinson's Disease, where patients who are medicated with a dopamine precursor tend to learn more about which options to engage with, whereas the same patients, after their medication has washed out, tend to learn which options should be avoided. In animal models, the specifics of this overarching theory have been tested more rigorously, showing that optogenetic manipulations of striatal D1 and D2 receptors can mimic the learning effects produced by DA and predicted by RL (Kravitz et al., 2010;Kravitz et al., 2012).

Through this lens, we might think of the synaptic connections between cortical afferents and striatal medium spiny cells as storing a set of action values, with different inputs from the cortex providing states that are connected to MSNs reflecting different candidate actions. This idea is supported by animal work showing that dendritic spines grow at specific synapses in response to precisely timed pairings of dopamine and glutamate (Yagishita et al., 2014). However, the broader idea that the cortical inputs themselves might represent states is a more complex issue. The translation from states to actions in reinforcement learning implies a certain flow of information from internal representations of the world (states) to actions. One key consideration is anatomical: the vast majority of connections within corticostriatal circuitry are topographic, with cortical regions connecting with specific striatal subregions that then connect to the same cortical region indirectly via the globus palidus and thalamus (Haber, 2003). This one-to-one projection topography produces parallel processing loops, roughly organized from limbic (OFC) to cognitive (dlPFC), to motor (premotor), which lack the means of translating one form of information (eg. states) into another (actions). However, thalamocortical connections provide a way to bridge connections between these loops, thereby effectively turning them into spirals. While many thalamo-cortical connections obey the basic "loop" topography, the thalamus also contains projections across topographic regions, typically feeding forward along the gradient from limbic to cognitive to motor regions (Haber, 2003). These connections provide a mechanism for hierarchical information processing in which goal selection achieved in limbic regions might drive cognitive actions, that in turn lead to cognitive representations, which serve as a sort of "state" onto which action values are learned. Computational modeling and fMRI data provide some support for this sort of hierarchical information processing in striato-cortical loops , however to date this idea is still largely theoretical.

div.head: What gets learned?
div.p: While reinforcement learning provides a useful framework for understanding how the brain can translate past experience into future behaviors, it is limited in the specificity of its predictions, largely because the same reinforcement learning algorithm can learn very different things from the same experience depending on the state space and action space that it is applied to. For example, if I miss my flight at the airport after trying to quickly get a coffee, I might learn narrowly from this experience not to wait for coffee at this particular coffee shop in this particular airport, or more broadly not to buy coffee when waiting for any flight, or even more broadly to dislike coffee altogether. In reinforcement learning, these different sorts of learning would be produced by different representations of state, ranging from specific (each state is defined narrowly) to general (states are defined broadly). Another crucial dimension of state information is observability; while some aspects of state might be observable (eg. being in a particular airport coffee shop), other aspects of my current situation may not be (eg. that my plane is currently boarding). Representation of this latter "latent state" information is crucial for accurately assigning credit in complex real world environments. In general, learning effectively requires choosing an appropriate state representation, since defining states too narrowly limits the degree to which the past can be used to predict the future (since each situation will be a novel state), but defining them too broadly limits behavioral flexibility (forcing me to dislike coffee in all situations, for example).

The brain appears to have multiple systems for representing states, ranging in their level of specificity, thereby allowing it to credit learning differently under different circumstances. Lesions to rodent and monkey orbitofrontal cortex disrupt improvements in serial reversal learning tasks consistent with the loss of abstract "latent" state representations (Robert C . While lesions to OFC in monkeys impair the specificity of credit assignment, this disruption appears to be due to a loss of fibers of passage, likely projecting from other prefrontal regions (Rudebeck & Murray, 2014). In humans, latent state representations have been observed in both orbitofrontal cortex (Jocham et al., 2016;Nassar, McGuire, et al., 2019;Schuck et al., 2016) as well as in dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (Vaidya & Badre, 2022). The precision of state representations in frontal cortical regions predicts the specificity of credit assignment across individuals (Jocham et al., 2016) and task conditions (Lamba et al., 2023) in simple experimental paradigms suggesting a functional role in the credit attribution process. Nonetheless, our understanding of how the brain represents the state of the world more in complex situations akin to the real world remains somewhat rudimentary and is an active area of research.

div.head: Beyond model-free reinforcement learning.
div.p: While the reinforcement learning algorithms described above have well established links to biology and can provide good descriptions of behavior in many experimental paradigms, they are limited in ways that people are not. The key limitation of these algorithms comes from the lack of a model, in its simplest form, an understanding of what will happen (in terms of the state I will arrive at and reward I will receive) after choosing a given action in a given state. For this reason, this class of algorithms is often referred to as model-free reinforcement learning. In short, model-free reinforcement learning algorithms choose actions because they have a high learned value -even though the algorithm itself is unaware of the specific consequences of those actions. Because of this, model free reinforcement learning algorithms are unable to re-evaluate action values according to changes in a reward function, for example, when rewards associated with a given food are devalued (either by allowing an animal free access to a specific food, or by pairing that food with lithium chloride). People clearly shift their preferences rapidly according to goals and reward context, raising questions about how the brain learns a model of the world and uses it to supplement model-free learning systems.

Rodent navigation research has provided a model-system for understanding what a state-state transition map might look like in the brain. Neurons in the hippocampus of freely moving rodents are tuned to specific locations, providing a representation of the animal's current state in terms of physical location. During navigation, hippocampal theta rhythms sweep through populations of these place cells leading to rapid activation of neurons extending outward from the animals current location to possible future locations, sometimes exploring multiple possible future paths vicariously (Redish, 2016). A similar phenomenon of ordered activation of place-tuned cells can be observed during sharp-wave ripple events that occur while animals are at rest (Carr et al., 2011). These events appear to play an important role in tasks that require learning contextual navigation policies, as optogenetic prolongation of the sharp wave events, which increases the spatial extent of concomitant sequential place cell activations, improves learning behavior in alternating t-mazes (Fernández-Ruiz et al., 2019). One interpretation of these phenomena is that the hippocampus learns to associate states with their successors, thereby providing a map through which to simulate the outcomes of a particular action plan. Such planning might be augmented through use of other interconnected regions of the medial temporal lobe, in particular the entorhinal cortex, where distributed grid-like spatial codes provide a lower-dimensional representation amenable to planning arbitrary spatial trajectories. The spatial map afforded by the medial temporal lobe constitutes a sufficient model for spatial navigation, which in principle could be used to plan action sequences directly, providing an alternative strategy for controlling behavior to the model-free reinforcement learning systems described above. Consistent with this idea, lesions to the hippocampus (along with other medial temporal regions) in humans leads to reduced model-based learning in tasks designed to disambiguate it from model free strategies (Vikbladh et al., 2019).

While it is clear that medial temporal lobe plays a crucial role in model-based learning, the exact computational role it plays is unclear. While some have argued that it serves as a substrate for planning, essentially acting as an alternative to striatal mechanisms, neuroimaging studies have struggled to disambiguate between these systems, and instead identified indications of model-based learning in ventral striatal BOLD responses that share common antecedents with striatal dopamine release and are thought to reflect model-free prediction errors (Rutledge et al., 2010). One alternative view is that hippocampal place fields might provide a very specific sort of state representation, called a successor representation, that represents states according to the discounted future state visitations expected from the current state. Model-free reinforcement learning applied to such successor representations often yields behaviors that look to be "model-based" (Gershman, 2018;Momennejad et al., 2017).

Another, non-exclusive computational role for medial temporal representations, is that it might implement a form of experience replay that can be used to provide offline training to model-free reinforcement learning systems. This idea is formulated in RL by the DYNA algorithm, which extends model free reinforcement learning by sampling random state-action pairs offline and looking up the state and reward that they would yield in a tabular model of the world. DYNA computes fictive prediction errors and learns from them just as it would learn from a real experience, yielding faster learning in terms of the number of actual interactions with the world, and promoting behaviors that more closely resemble optimal model-based planning. While DYNA samples experiences from its model randomly, normative solutions to experience sampling have provided insights into the exact patterns of replay in rodents (Mattar & Daw, 2018) and humans (Liu et al., 2021). In principle, replay could be used to translate model-based knowledge in the hippocampus into better action values in the striatum, explaining the existence of model-based information in the striatum (Daw et al., 2011), however this would require coordination of the striatum and hippocampus during replay. Testing this idea is an important next step for understanding the role of replay phenomena in the hippocampus.

The medial temporal lobe is closely connected to the orbitofrontal cortex, which according to lesion studies, is also necessary for model based learning. Lesions to monkey OFC, including excitotoxic fiberspairing lesions, impair the ability of monkeys to select options according to updated preferences in a devaluation paradigm (Murray & Izquierdo, 2007;Rudebeck & Murray, 2014). This pattern of results does not reflect a lack of motivation for the preferred food option, as lesioned monkeys have no difficulty inhibiting their selection of the devalued food option when they can see it directly, suggesting that OFC plays a role in linking states or state-actions to their consequences (Murray & Izquierdo, 2007). This has led some researchers to propose that OFC, along with hippocampus, provides a cognitive map (Wikenheiser & Schoenbaum, 2016), with OFC particularly important for representing states that are not directly observable (Robert C , perhaps including states of food-specific satiety.

div.head: How much to learn?
div.p: One major question that is not addressed by standard reinforcement learning algorithms is how *much* should a person learn from a new experience. Reinforcement learning states that we might update expectations, for example about the value of a particular action, according to a prediction error. But it is silent on how much we should do so, instead providing a fixed parameter, the learning rate, to control the influence of prediction errors associated with each new experience. This flies in the face of human experience, as we clearly perceive some experiences to be highly influential on our beliefs and behavioral patterns and others to be utterly inconsequential.

One normative interpretation of this basic tenet of human experience can be derived from Bayesian inference models, particularly those that attempt to use data collected in the past in order to infer what to expect in the future. Such models form beliefs about the underlying state of a system, for example about reward rate, and highlight the importance of assumptions regarding the stability of the environment. One class of models, referred to as Kalman filters, provide a Bayesian solution to this prediction problem in stable or steadily drifting environments. In the absence of a consistent drift in a particular direction, such models boil down mathematically to the same prediction error learning rule described above (as described in Rescorla Wagner section), except that the degree to which prediction errors are used to update beliefs is controlled by the Kalman Gain, which is updated on each trial according to uncertainty about the underlying process (eg. reward rate). The dynamics of such models are somewhat unimpressive, because as observations increase, the Kalman filter converges on a fixed stable Kalman gain that depends on irreducible uncertainty (how variable are rewards around the true mean reward rate) and the drift rate (how much does the reward rate change from trial to trial).

Other Bayesian models have captured dynamics in human learning by applying Bayesian inference to more interesting generative models that involve changes in the drift rate. Behrens and colleagues considered a reward rate whose drift rate is, in turn, also drifting. They showed that inference over such a model captured fluctuations in the degree of learning that participants showed in a task that included both stable and so-called "volatile" blocks with reward rate transitions -as the model accurately predicted higher learning rates in the latter. The authors also showed that the inferred rate of drift, which closely tracked learning, was related to feedback-locked BOLD response in dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (Behrens et al., 2007), an area thought to be involved in performance monitoring (Li et al., 2019;Shenhav et al., 2013b). While this class of Bayesian models provide a normative interpretation of common behavioral tendencies at the group level, they fail to explain the large differences in learning rates across individuals. One extension of this framework, called the Hierarchical Gaussian Filter, provides variational tools to fit models composed of hierarchical drift rates directly to behavioral data, providing interpretations of individual differences in terms of the expectations individuals bring to the table about the structure of their environment (Mathys et al., 2014).

An alternative approach to modeling environmental change has relied on assumptions that the environment undergoes occasional, but extreme, changes (Adams & MacKay, 2007;Wilson et al., 2013;Yu & Dayan, 2005). Bayesian inference in such an environment requires drastically resetting beliefs after perceived changepoints (Adams & MacKay, 2007;Wilson et al., 2013), and can be approximated by an error-driven learning rule (same equations as Rescorla Wagner rule) in which the learning rate is adjusted from moment-to-moment according to 1) the probability that a newly observed data point reflects a changepoint and 2) the relative level of reducible, as opposed to irreducible, uncertainty, akin to a dynamic version of the Kalman Gain. In predictive inference tasks, where participants next predict the next in a series of outcomes, people are sensitive to both of these factors, adjusting learning rates dynamically at changepoints (1) and reducing their sensitivity to new information as their uncertainty about the underlying mean is reduced (2) (McGuire & Kable, 2012;McGuire et al., 2014;Nassar et al., 2010). Both factors that affect learning are evident in the BOLD response in dmPFC (McGuire et al., 2014), as well as in fluctuations in pupil diameter (Nassar et al., 2012), which reflect transient changes in arousal thought to be related to underlying neuromodulatory state (Joshi & Gold, 2020), and in particular levels of norepinephrine (Joshi et al., 2016). These results raise an interesting possibility, which is that neural systems might employ a dynamic learning rate to modulate the gain of incoming information (Aston-Jones & Cohen, 2005;Mather et al., 2016;Usher et al., 1999).

However, more recent work has raised questions about this possibility. One primary issue with the notion of a global learning rate adjustment signal in the brain is that, while such signals are readily observable in specific statistical contexts (eg. tasks involving changepoints) they are highly context dependent. For example, the magnitude of feedback locked P300 signals, measured via EEG, positively relate to the degree of learning from feedback and track dynamic learning rate adjustments in changing environments (Fischer & Ullsperger, 2013;Jepma et al., 2016). However, the same signals negatively relate to learning in tasks with an alternate "oddball" statistical structure, in which outlying data points should be ignored, rather than learned from (Nassar, Bruckner, et al., 2019). Similarly, dmPFC BOLD signals that relate positively to learning rate in changing environments (Behrens et al., 2007;McGuire et al., 2014), do not do so across both changepoint and oddball conditions (d 'Acremont & Bossaerts, 2016). Pupil dilations, which positively correlate with learning in tasks with changepoint structures (Nassar et al., 2012), negatively correlate with learning in ones that contain oddballs (O'Reilly et al., 2013). Context-dependent learning. How learning unfolds depends on the context. As reviewed above, under assumptions of a stable environment, a prior belief is updated proportional to the prediction error (top left). Two additional learning scenarios are considered: a change point environment, in which the state of the environment can abruptly change (top center), and an oddball environment, in which freak events occasionally occur without any bearing on the future (top right). These contexts lead to distinct belief updates depending on the observation (bottom). When observations fall close to the prior, they are most likely to have been generated from the expected prior distribution, thereby driving similar incremental belief updates under all three environmental assumptions (bottom left). As prediction errors increase and the probability that the observation could be drawn from the expected prior distribution decreases, learning across the contexts diverges (bottom middle/right). In change-point environments, the greater the prediction error, the greater the probability that the prior is no longer valid, and a new, uncertain state was entered, driving proportionally larger updates, since in this case the newest observation is the only one relevant to the current state of the system. Conversely, the larger the prediction error in the oddball environment, the greater the probability that the observation was drawn from the oddball distribution, and thus will have no bearing on future observations. Thus large errors under the oddball assumption drive minimal updates, and in the extreme as the probability of an oddball event goes to one, no update occurs at all.

This lack of consistency in learning signals has led to a re-evaluation of learning rate adjustments in terms of latent state inference (Gershman & Niv, 2010;Yu et al., 2020). In this view, learning rate dynamics emerge via rapid transitions in mental context signals that serve as a substrate for new associative learning processes (Razmi & Nassar, 2022). Such a framework provides a normative solution to learning in dynamic environments if these mental context representations provide an accurate inference over latent states of the world that control the mapping between actions and their outcomes. A model that implements this basic idea captures not only behavior in different learning contexts (changepoints and oddballs) but also provides an explanation for the contextual learning signals observed in the brain under these different conditions. In particular, signals used by the model to update mental context are positively related to learning in changepoint environments, where such signals are used to facilitate rapid behavioral shifts, but negatively related to learning in oddball environments, where such signals are used to partition oddball events in order to minimize interference (Razmi & Nassar, 2022) (Fig 3). These update signals force rapid transitions of the mental context at changepoints and oddballs, leading to a pattern of similarity across trials closely resembling that observed previously in OFC (Nassar, McGuire, et al., 2019). Beyond providing an explanation for brain signals, this model affords increased flexibility, in that it provides a mechanism to reuse information from a previous context in environments that contain repetitive structures, such as reversals or sequences (Yu et al., 2020). Thus, while there is certainly more work to be done on the topic, the latent states framework provides a parsimonious explanation for a wide range of data on the dynamics of learning, and potentially reframes the question of "how much should be learned?" into a slightly different one "what state should learning be assigned to?".

div.head: Decision making
div.p: So far, we have reviewed how people learn the values of different actions and how they vary across contexts that are sometimes hidden from the learner's eyes. In what follows, we will review how they decide what action to take, and do so flexibly across contexts. Decision-making is an integral aspect of navigating one's environment. As organisms that are able to move and interact with our environment in myriad ways, we are faced with the problem of picking one of them. Oh, to be seagrass sometimes and just move with the currents! In some contexts, choosing correctly can be a matter of life and death, for instance, when deciding whether or not that orangy patch in the distant bushes is a lion to run from, or perhaps more relatably, whether or not it is safe to cross the street before the approaching car passes by. In many other instances of modern life, decisions are less likely to be fatal, but they can still make the difference between a happy and healthy life and one that is neither. A helpful way to think about how decisions are made is through the lens of predictive inference. As described earlier for learning, predictive inference helps to identify what state one is in, what the right thing to do is, etc. The key difference to learning as described above is that in decision-making, this iterative updating process occurs prior to rather than after taking an action. The basic mechanism is similar: beliefs are updated based on samples, for instance, by repeatedly looking at the orangy patch, we come to some conclusion as to whether or not it is a tiger with some certainty. We can then follow with an appropriate action, though that might be another decision… People make different kinds of decisions. Two widely studied classes are perceptual decision-making and value-based decision-making. The former are akin to our tiger example: the decision-maker identifies a property of its environment through perception. The outcome of the decision is a label that reflects the quality of this property: lion vs no lion, has more dots than the other box, or moving to the right rather than the left. These types of decisions typically have a ground truth to them that can be externally validated. Value-based decisions on the other hand are typically subjective and depend on the decision-maker's values. While I might always choose the breakfast croissant with tofu scramble at my local brunch place, my friend might consistently go for the breakfast burrito and each of us would feel we made the best choice. Such value-based decision-making can extend beyond the selection of individual, concrete options . People also decide what strategies to use to perform a given task (including making a decision), and they decide what task to do at any given time, when to switch, when to stop, whether to engage with an option or not. All of these decisions can be thought of as balancing a trade-off between the costs and benefits associated with one option compared to another. These costs and benefits are typically subjectively evaluated, for instance some people may value accuracy over effort and might then use a different strategy than people with opposite values.

How decisions unfold in time and result in choices and response times has been modeled successfully using sequential sampling models (Bogacz et al., 2007;Colas, 2017;Forstmann et al., 2016;Ratcliff & Smith, 2004;Ratcliff et al., 2016;Usher & McClelland, 2001). In this general class of models, noisy information is sampled sequentially and evidence in favor of either option is accumulated over time, until it reaches an evidence criterion, or decision-bound, at which time a decision for the winning option is made. This integration process helps stabilize decisions in the face of uncertainty and optimizes a tradeoff between accuracy and decision-time. The more information is sampled the higher the probability that the ultimate choice is correct, yet at a certain point, the increment in expected accuracy may no longer outweigh the cost of sampling time. The most commonly used type of sequential sampling models is the drift diffusion model in which a decision variable reflecting the accumulated evidence for one of two options is accumulated over time to a fixed threshold triggering a categorical decision (Fig 4). The speed with which evidence accumulates is denoted by the drift rate, a parameter that scales with the strength of the signal (e.g., the proportion of dots coherently moving in the same direction, or the difference in value among potential options). For two-alternative choice, the DDM has two symmetric bounds, one for each option, and a decision is made when the accumulated evidence crosses one of these bounds. The starting point for evidence accumulation can either be unbiased right between those bounds, or biased towards one of the options bounds. Under the assumption that the accumulated evidence reflects the log likelihood ratio associated with two alternatives, and that the starting position of the diffusion process reflects the prior probabilities of the two alternatives, the drift diffusion model guarantees the fastest decision that achieves a given level of confidence (Wald, 1945). A decision is made if accumulated evidence hits one of two bounds, one for each option. The rate at which evidence accumulates (drift rate) depends on the signal strength of the input and higher drift rates lead to faster and more accurate decisions. The threshold determines how much evidence is required and higher thresholds are associated with slower and more accurate decisions. Typically, evidence accumulation starts in the middle of the two bounds, however, any response biases (e.g. because lions are particularly common in that patch of the woods), can be implemented in a starting point bias that shifts the initial evidence towards one of the responses (e.g. lion). Non-decision processes, like visual and motor processes are modeled as non-decision time and comprised in response times alongside accumulation-determined decision times.

Biases in the start point of the diffusion process are often observed when one type of decision is more likely (e.g., lions are rather rare in cities, so the orangy blob is probably not a lion), or a so-called default option (e.g., when you have a favorite dish in your local restaurant that you always tend to get). In addition to these core parameters, the DDM decomposes response times into decision-times arising from the drift diffusion process, and a non-decision time that encompasses simple perceptual and motor processes. Unlike other models, the drift diffusion-model is a perfect integrator, that is, no information is lost in the process. In contrast to other models (Bogacz et al., 2007;Hunt & Hayden, 2017;Usher & McClelland, 2001;Wang, 2002), in the DDM options compete via their inputs, rather than at the level of accumulator activation, so that evidence accumulates linearly, through summation. Despite these differences, all sequential sampling models involve some kind of evidence integration over time and a decision-rule. Whereas in perceptual decision-making, the information that is sampled is perceptual, value-based choice is believed to rely on information sampled from memory (Bakkour et al., 2018;Shadlen & Shohamy, 2016).

Grounded in the successes of sequential sampling models, research has sought to identify how these processes are implemented in the brain. This work has built from success in animal models, initially in rhesus macacques performing dot motion tasks in which low coherence stimuli force subjects to integrate evidence over long periods of time, thereby separating visual responses to the stimulus from motor responses related to choice. Within such tasks early work showed that neurons in motion sensitive visual area MT reflected the momentary evidence corresponding to the frame-by-frame motion energy in the random dot stimulus (Britten et al., 1993). In contrast, neurons more closely linked to the saccadic eye systems used to signal a response, such as lateral intraparietal area (LIP) and frontal eye field (FEF) showed dynamic activity profiles across stimulus presentation that match predictions of evidence accumulation in a drift diffusion model (Ding & Gold, 2011;Roitman & Shadlen, 2002). Neurons in these regions show tuning for saccadic responses to specific locations (response fields) and experiments typically involve placing the response target for one perceptual decision (ie. reporting rightward motion) in the response field of a recorded neuron. Such experiments revealed that neurons in LIP and FEF, in addition to showing increased firing rates when monkeys saccade to the target in the response field, firing rates also ramped up during preceding motion viewing as if accumulating evidence for the choice corresponding to the neurons response field (Roitman & Shadlen, 2002). In contrast, the same neurons showed downward ramping firing rates while viewing motion stimuli preceding an out-of-response-field choice, with firing rates decreasing faster when motion evidence favoring the out-of-response-field choice was stronger. The activity of these evidence accumulation neurons reached a common maximal level of activity immediately preceding the monkey making a saccade into the response field, which has been interpreted as as a neural signature of crossing the threshold in a drift diffusion model (Gold & Shadlen, 2002). These results present a remarkable neural analogy to the drift diffusion model and sequential sampling; whereby neurons in LIP and FEF accumulate momentary evidence relayed by motion sensitive aread MT in order to select a response in a timely manner.

While mapping the principles of evidence accumulation onto specific cortical circuitry has been one of the major advances in decision making research this century, the actual neural implementation likely involves considerably more complexity. For example, subcortical regions, in particular the striatum, also contain information about accumulated decision evidence (Ding & Gold, 2013) and appear to play a causal role in making perceptual decisions (Doi et al., 2020;Yartsev et al., 2018). On the other hand, work in rodents and monkeys using invasive technology to activate and silence purported cortical accumulated evidence regions, has triggered debate about whether parietal cortical regions solely reflect evidence accumulation, rather than implementing it (Erlich et al., 2015;Hanks et al., 2015;Katz et al., 2016;Yartsev et al., 2018). However, recent work has highlighted that there are multiple regions capable of performing evidence accumulation, and that animals can rapidly compensate for temporary lesions by relying on alternative systems (Jeurissen et al., 2022). Thus, even though drift diffusion models provide a remarkable throughline from normative guarantees of sequential sampling to ramping activity profiles of parietal and prefrontal neurons, there still work to be done in assigning exact computational roles to specific brain regions.

For value-based choice, putative evidence accumulation signals have been identified in orbitofrontal cortex, both in non-human primates as well as in humans. Neurons in monkey orbitofronal cortex represent value of various alternatives in a common currency (Padoa-Schioppa & Assad, 2008). These neurons appear to play a causal role in value based decision making (Ballesta et al., 2020), which in some cases involves alternatively representing the values associated with multiple choice options, as if considering different alternative possibilities (Rich & Wallis, 2016). Others have found signatures of value based decision making in the dorsolateral Striatum. In humans, correlates of evidence accumulation have been found in vmPFC (Hunt et al., 2012), in dACC (Hare et al., 2011), in the centroparietal positivity (O'Connell et al., 2012), likely originating in ACC (Pisauro et al., 2017), and in motor potentials, such as the readiness potential and the lateralized readiness potential (Gluth et al., 2013a). Identifying true signatures of evidence accumulation is notoriously difficult, because processes other than evidence accumulation can masquerade as integration processes in averages (Froemer et al., 2022;Stine et al., 2020), and because activity can correlate with evidence accumulation for reasons other than generating the decision, e.g. for monitoring or response implementation. In sum, while putative evidence accumulation signals abound across the brain, the puzzle of how the brain makes decisions remains far from solved.

Evidence accumulation, and by extension behavior, varies with processes that affect its inputs. Evidence integration can be biased by making certain inputs more salient than others (Kunar et al., 2017;Tsetsos et al., 2012). As these inputs are attended more, they receive greater weight in the integration processes and thus more strongly affect behavior. The influence of attention on value-based choice has been implemented in an extension of the DDM, the aDDM, whereby currently unattended items are down-weighted relative to currently attended items (Krajbich et al., 2010). This model and its variants have successfully explained choice biases, such as a greater likelihood of choosing items that are attended more (in the appetitive domain, and vice versa in the aversive domain). Following this ground-breaking work, more and more findings that were assumed to reflect preferences, such as delay discounting (Lempert & Phelps, 2016), or biases, such as nonlinear probability weighting (Zilker & Pachur, 2021), have been shown to vary as a function of gaze allocation. Another factor that has been shown to influence evidence accumulation is the confidence with which one assigns value to an option. As for attention, all else being equal, greater confidence in an options' value boosted the impact of its value and increased the probability that the option would be chosen (in the appetitive domain and likely vice versa in the aversive domain) (Lee & Coricelli, 2020). Similar to attention, this effect has been modeled within the DDM framework with confidence modulating the weight an option's value is given in the integration process (Lee & Usher, 2020). A common theme across this research, specifically with regard to the underlying computational mechanisms, has been the assumption that these factors merely affect the way information is integrated and that they are otherwise independent of the decision and one another. Recent work disputes these assumptions and offers a richer picture of the mechanisms involved in decision-making with striking implications for interpreting neural correlates of choice.

Recent work has demonstrated that gaze is not random, but allocated optimally so as to reduce uncertainty in a goal-directed way (Callaway et al., 2021;Jang et al., 2021). This work used Bayesian implementations of sequential sampling models (Tajima et al., 2016), that are in spirit similar to a simple, but elegant extension of the aDDM whereby attention is allocated in proportion to the evidence that has been accumulated for each item at a given point in time (Gluth et al., 2020). In detail, however, in these models gaze is not only allocated to the most likely winning option(s), it is also allocated to options that are at that time more uncertain, and more likely to change the ultimate choice if sampled (Callaway et al., 2021;Jang et al., 2021). Thus, at each point in time, decision-makers decide whether to keep sampling the current option, shift their gaze to one of the alternatives and if so which one, or whether to stop sampling altogether and commit to the currently winning option ( Fig 5A). They also need to represent information feeding into these decisions, such as the momentary value and uncertainty estimates for each option. Importantly, these models reverse the interpretation of commonly observed coupling between attention and choice. In these models, such correlations do not arise primarily because attention impacts information integration -although it might -but because a latent choice representation guides attention towards the option that is ultimately chosen. Thus, the decision process feeds back into itself. Decision-makers determine not only which, but also how information is integrated. People integrate information in light of the choice context (Spektor et al., 2021;Tymula & Plassmann, 2016), whereby for instance options appear better in the context of poorer options and worse in the context of better options (Khaw et al., 2017), and they seem to discount unreliable information during evidence integration (Geuzebroek et al., 2022). Bayesian inference, or efficient coding, has offered a useful framework for explaining context effects (Bhui & Gershman, 2018;Polanía et al., 2019), as well as uncertainty-weighted evidence integration (Denison et al., 2017;Denison et al., 2018;Li & Ma, 2020). Within this framework, a prior, representing the likely distribution of, say, values in value-based choice, or perceptual features in perceptual choice, is iteratively updated via sequential sampling . Ideally, this prior is well-tuned to the statistics of the current choice environment, enabling fast and robust estimation of the relevant feature ( Fig 5B). In such a model, unlike in the DDM and its variants, evidence integration is not linear via summation, but Bayes-optimal, dependent on uncertainty. This framework also nicely accommodates effects of prior knowledge, attention and confidence on evidence integration via a shared, uncertainty-weighted updating mechanism . In a sequential presentation paradigm, that prohibits goal-directed gaze allocation by manipulating when and how long options are each presented on the screen, we could isolate how they shape evidence integration, specifically. We found that attention and confidence both shaped value-based choices in a reference-dependent manner. That is, options that were more valuable than the average option in the experiment were more likely to be chosen when attended more or when participants had higher confidence in its value, whereas under the same conditions, options less valuable than the average option were less likely to be chosen. Bayesian inference with a prior that is well calibrated to the true distribution of values in the task can explain all of these effects.

There is a growing recognition that people flexibly adapt how they make decisions to their current goals (De Martino & Cortese, 2023;Molinaro & Collins, 2023). In the perceptual domain, like in research on cognitive control, it has long been established that task goals, such as motion versus color discrimination, guide information processing in the service of decision-making, for instance by allowing for the selection of the relevant feature, or by linking these features to the required actions (Vaidya & Badre, 2022). In the value-based domain, choice goals have been considered with regard to their influence on the computation of subjective values, which constitute the inputs to the decision-process. A common example is the change in option valuation when choosing for taste compared to choosing for health. Much like focusing on different features of perceptual stimuli, it was considered that people may also focus on different attributes of options, which may change the subjective value computation for the option accordingly (Harris et al., 2018;Hutcherson et al., 2012;Tusche & Hutcherson, 2018). Recently, work has shown that rather than a form of expected reward upon consumption, what drives value based choices is how congruent an option's values are with one's goal (Frömer et al., 2019). To reveal this, on half of the trials we asked participants as usual to choose the option they liked the best, and on the remaining half, we instead asked them to choose the item they liked the least. We found that under this new goal, the typical result, that people choose faster when all options are more highly valued compared to less highly valued, reversed. The typical response speeding with overall value was previously thought to perhaps reflect an instance of reward-driven increases in vigor (Niv, Daw, et al., 2006;Niv et al., 2007;Niv, Joel, et al., 2006). Yet, now people were faster to choose among poor options compared to desirable options. Computationally, this finding can be explained by a change in how value is used in the decision-making process. Rather than accumulating value per se, our simulations suggest that people represent value in a goal-directed manner, whereby high values constitute little evidence when the goal is to choose the worst option. Practically, inverting the value scale (assigning 0 to an option rated as 10 and 10 to an option rated as 0) was sufficient to reproduce the key empirical findings in a leaky competing accumulator model (Frömer et al., 2019;Usher & McClelland, 2001). Subsequent work showed that task goals and constraints also shape attentional priorities, how gaze is allocated and thereby what the inputs are at a given point in time (Sepulveda et al., 2020;Teoh et al., 2020).

How does the brain afford this flexible, goal-directed decision-making? Previous work has shown that flexible decision-making is afforded in at least two ways, paralleling adjustments in the decision-inputs reviewed above. One, the brain adjusts which features are represented and selected for the decision computation. For instance, choosing options based on the number of faces on a poster, i.e., a perceptual features recruits the fronto-parietal attention network (including Intraparietal Sulcus, Frontal Eye Fields, and Lateral Occipital Complex), and shows encoding of the face value of the options within this network, whereas for the same stimuli choosing based on value instead recruits the canonical valuation network (including ventral Striatum, medial orbitofrontal cortex, vmPFC and posterior cingulate cortex), and shows encoding of subjective value within this network (Grueschow et al., 2015). Within each domain, again, feature encoding depends on the relevant choice dimension, whether it is color versus motion discrimination in the perceptual domain (Ritz & Shenhav, 2023) or the health versus taste value in the value-based domain (Hutcherson et al., 2012;Tusche & Hutcherson, 2018). Two, the brain adjusts the format of the representations that decision-making operates on to align them with one's goals. In the choose best, choose worst task above, we found that rather than value per se, the brain appears to represent how goal-congruent an option's value is for the current goal (Frömer et al., 2019). Similarly, others have found that the neural code of an object represents how useful it is for a momentary goal, such as tying a knot or lighting a fire (Castegnetti et al., 2021). If options can have multiple task dependent values, such that sometimes color and sometimes movement features of stimuli are associated with reward, then the vmPFC represents both values and selects among them through interactions with simultaneous task representations (Moneta et al., 2023). However, having competing features and/or values leads to interference and the need for control (Moneta et al., 2023;Ritz & Shenhav, 2023), which is widely considered as costly (Shenhav et al., 2017;Westbrook & Braver, 2015).

It has been proposed that decision-making, and accumulating evidence, may in itself be effortful and/or costly (Drugowitsch et al., 2012), particularly when options are mutually exclusive (Leng et al., 2023). This may be one reason why people experience decision fatigue, and exhibit forms of decision avoidance (Anderson, 2003), such as status quo bias (Fleming et al., 2010), choice deferral (Bhatia & Mullett, 2016;Gluth et al., 2013b), or even decision paralysis (Huber et al., 2012). Research suggests that when possible, people select decision strategies that minimize effort (Seaman et al., 2018;Westbrook et al., 2013). For instance, when choosing among many options, rather than accumulating evidence for all of them, people focus on a small subset of promising candidates and sometimes even abort evidence accumulation early when encountering special favourite items (Thomas et al., 2021). People also respond to no-brainer trials that are interspersed in regular intertemporal choice trials as if they switched strategies as soon as they detect the irregular trial (Lin et al., 2018). In intertemporal choice, people are offered a smaller more immediate reward or a larger more delayed reward. Since delayed rewards are discounted, people typically integrate delay and reward to compute a discounted reward and then choose based on these discounted values. It seems that on no-brainer trials where the same reward is offered for varying delays or different rewards for the same delay, people abort this usual integration strategy to go straight for the shorter delay or the larger reward. Another way in which people may reduce decision costs is by recycling decisions they have already made in the past (Dasgupta & Gershman, 2021). That is, rather than engaging in effortful decision computations, they may rely on memory and repeat choices they have made before. Thus, decision-making is flexible and hierarchical in that higher order decisions are made about how and possibly whether decisions are being made at all .

How does the brain coordinate this hierarchy of decisions? Work across multiple species and methods has shown that the brain shows abstract, hierarchical goal/task representations across multiple networks across the brain that support flexible decision-making. Across these networks, research has identified gradients along which task knowledge is represented with increasing levels of abstraction. For instance, separate task set representations were identified in the MTL-OMPFC network encompassing vmPFC, OFC, Entorhinal Cortex and Hippocampus, and in the frontoparietal attention network, including dlPFC and lateral parietal cortex. In each network, these representations gradually increased in abstraction from rostral to caudal, and have been proposed to differ between these networks in format rather than in content (Vaidya & Badre, 2022). Specifically, the authors proposed that the MTL-OMPFC network represented task knowledge in a declarative format for flexible planning and inference, whereas the frontoparietal network represented this knowledge in the form of productions that afford control. It is thought that higher order control decisions are computed in dorsal Anterior Cingulate Cortex (ACC) (Shenhav et al., 2013a;Shenhav et al., 2021). Here, too, research has identified a rostral-caudal gradient with strategy control, choice control, and response control recruiting increasingly caudal regions of ACC (Venkatraman et al., 2009). Consistent with this idea, in a voluntary task switching paradigm using motion vs color discrimination, caudal ACC has been found to track evidence accumulation for individual responses, whereas more rostral regions tracked evidence accumulation for attention selection between the two features of stimuli based on choice difficulty and incentives (Shenhav et al., 2018). Thus, the brain holds in mind relevant information about goals and available tasks and aligns information processing according to its current choices, while leaving open the possibility to flexibly change course through changes of mind about these higher order decisions.

div.head: Shared computations
div.p: The inclined reader may have noticed that learning and decision-making share a set of common computations and that both can be understood within the framework of Bayesian inference. To put it extremely simply, in both cases, the agent relies on some type of prediction, for instance about the reward expected from a candidate action, to determine what to do. In both cases, this prediction is iteratively refined through additional information that is sampled about candidate actions or the states that define the values of each. In reinforcement learning, this information is typically obtained through overt action, whereas in decision-making, this information is obtained via sampling through gaze or from memory. What information is obtained is far from accidental -people systematically explore more informative options, for instance those that are more uncertain (Boldt et al., 2019; and more promising (Callaway et al., 2021), and they systematically adjust how they explore to the current context, for instance sampling more efficiently and less when sampling comes at greater opportunity cost or when there's less opportunity for extended sampling to pay off down the line (Teoh et al., 2020;. As mentioned earlier, coordinating sampling in this way requires a sense of one's uncertainty in behaviorally relevant variables that can be sampled. It has been proposed that core circuitry of both learning and decision-making, including dACC is involved in sampling decisions and/or the representation of relevant uncertainties (Hunt et al., 2021;Monosov, 2020;Trudel et al., 2020;White et al., 2019). ACC in particular is also frequently associated with metacognition (Vaccaro & Fleming, 2018), or monitoring more generally (Ridderinkhof et al., 2004;Ullsperger et al., 2014). It is thus no surprise that these general demand networks are shared across learning and decision-making.

Once obtained, information also needs to be integrated to update existing beliefs and refine behaviorally relevant predictions. In both learning and decision-making, this appears to be done in a manner that takes into account the precision of both the existing belief as well as the expected precision of the sampled information, which can be read out as confidence Frömer et al., 2021). Samples assigned high confidence will shape our momentary beliefs and thus guide our actions more strongly than the same samples assigned low confidence; conversely, the same sample will shape our beliefs more strongly when those beliefs are weaker, for instance because they are based on little or variable evidence, than when they are stronger, based on much consistent prior observations. Likewise, how the same information is interpreted is highly contingent on one's beliefs about the current context (Khaw et al., 2017;Nassar, Bruckner, et al., 2019;Polanía et al., 2019). The same information can increase or decrease our probability of taking an action, for instance when that observation indicates a change has happened or that this action is likely to yield a better or worse outcome than alternative options, or it might not impact what we do at all, because the observation is likely to be a freak event that has no bearing on the future or because it matches our weak expectations of what we should observe in a given context. What this means is that in both learning and decision-making, how information is processed is highly contextual and yet again, contingent on one's current assessment of where one is and one's metacognition. These assessments are again linked to regions that are active in learning and decision-making, including vmPFC and OFC (Gershman & Uchida, 2019;Koban et al., 2021;Vaidya & Badre, 2022;Walton et al., 2015).

Another factor that we have touched on is higher-order cost-benefit computations. Is the effort required to make the best possible decision worthwhile? Is the effort required to learn in the most efficient way worthwhile? Research in decision-making has begun to unravel how cost-benefit computations shape how long information is sampled for (Drugowitsch et al., 2012;Gluth et al., 2012;Kobayashi et al., 2021;Tajima et al., 2016), and satisficing, whereby decision-makers settle for the first option that satisfies a minimum criterion, i.e. is good enough, is a well-established concept in the field of judgement and decision-making (Bruckner et al., 2020). This framework leads to an anchor and adjust framework for learning that has also been linked to counternormative biases in decisions from description (Kahneman & Tversky, 1972), but might also be thought of as a way to rationally allocate resources for effective learning (Lieder et al., 2018). There is also an established distinction between goal-directed decision-making, as we have covered above, and habitual decision-making (Balleine & O'Doherty, 2010;Niv, 2009), whereby habitual responding, really is no longer decision-making in the strict sense, since actions are selected merely based on their association with the current context, rather than through comparison of expected outcomes (Miller et al., 2019). This is one way in which agents minimize decision effort and we have briefly discussed others above, including sticking with defaults (Fleming et al., 2010) or recycling from memory (Dasgupta & Gershman, 2021). It has been proposed that similar cost-benefit computations are applied in learning, for instance people may not learn the best possible policy, but rather trade off costs associated with policy complexity with its benefits (Gershman, 2020;Lai & Gershman, 2021). If the costs associated with differentiating action values across all possible states are not justified through corresponding increases in rewards, states will be lumped together, i.e. the policy will be compressed. Likewise, whether agents invest time to improve on a given task rather than optimizing their local reward rate through fast responding (Masís et al., 2023) or selection of alternate tasks (Masís et al., 2021), also seems to be driven by cost-benefit decisions. These cost-benefit decisions in turn shape other computations, including sampling and inference, and are thus important to understand, integrate with, but also separate from other computations and their neural implementations.

div.head: Conclusions:
div.p: Understanding learning and decision-making in the brain will require that we look beyond the narrow borders of either of them, consider them jointly, and look for overlap and differences in other domains, such as cognitive control or affect, to just give a few examples. While reductionist approaches have isolated specific mechanisms at play in simple paradigms to yield considerable insights, we remain well short of a concrete mechanistic explanation of learning and decision making in the wild (FeldmanHall & Nassar, 2021). Thus, while learning and decision making are areas of cognition where we have truly linked computations to the neural mechanisms that perform them, there is still considerable work to be done to understand how these mechanisms contend with the complex dynamics of everyday life to give rise to the broader human experience. As we chip away at these open questions, we may well find that some of what we currently believe needs to be substantially revised.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 1. Framework for learning and decision making. Learning and decision-making involve use of prior knowledge from previous experience as well as momentary sensory information in order to compute key decision variables, such as the values of available cognitive and physical actions. These decision variables guide selection of cognitive actions, including the decision to collect more information from the external environment or internal knowledge stores (white dotted lines), as well as physical actions, for example to order a specific item on the menu. Feedback about such actions is provided in the form of a new experience, which in turn shapes both internal knowledge structures through learning as well as the observable sensory environment (black dotted lines). Decision making research typically focuses on how decision variables are formed and used to select actions, whereas learning research typically focuses on how new experience shapes internal representations that drive behavior. Nonetheless, these processes are intertwined and share a common computational framework that contains elements including information sampling, context dependent belief updating, and higher order cost-benefit decisions that guide how these computations unfold.

figure.head: Figure 3 .
figure.figDesc: Figure 3. Context-dependent learning. How learning unfolds depends on the context. As reviewed above, under assumptions of a stable environment, a prior belief is updated proportional to the prediction error (top left). Two additional learning scenarios are considered: a change point environment, in which the state of the environment can abruptly change (top center), and an oddball environment, in which freak events occasionally occur without any bearing on the future (top right). These contexts lead to distinct belief updates depending on the observation (bottom). When observations fall close to the prior, they are most likely to have been generated from the expected prior distribution, thereby driving similar incremental belief updates under all three environmental assumptions (bottom left). As prediction errors increase and the probability that the observation could be drawn from the expected prior distribution decreases, learning across the contexts diverges (bottom middle/right). In change-point environments, the greater the prediction error, the greater the probability that the prior is no longer valid, and a new, uncertain state was entered, driving proportionally larger updates, since in this case the newest observation is the only one relevant to the current state of the system. Conversely, the larger the prediction error in the oddball environment, the greater the probability that the observation was drawn from the oddball distribution, and thus will have no bearing on future observations. Thus large errors under the oddball assumption drive minimal updates, and in the extreme as the probability of an oddball event goes to one, no update occurs at all.

figure.head: Figure 4 .
figure.figDesc: Drift Diffusion model. Decisions are made by repeatedly sampling noisy inputs and accumulating evidence across samples.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Attention and confidence in value-based decision-making. A. At each point in time, the agent needs to decide whether to accumulate more evidence about the current option, switch attention to alternative options, or decide based on the current evidence. Momentary evidence of attended items has greater precision than from unattended options. Both are used to update options' value estimates using Bayes rule.(Figure adaptedfrom Jang et al. 2021) B. Value estimation depends on expectations. Expectations are calibrated to one's environment. C. Value estimation depends on confidence in values. Confidence scales the precision of the samples and thereby the magnitude of the update. D. Sampling and confidence similarly affect deviations of momentary estimates from true values. During choice, all else being equal, these deviations lead to systematic choice biases. (B.-D. adapted fromFrömer, Callaway, Griffiths & Shenhav, 2022)
